data.title: First German Baptist Church Southside Pittsburgh
data.text:
The Southside Pittsburgh First German Baptist Church records contain information on births, marriages, children, immigration, and conversion to the Baptist faith for many members of the church. However, we know that these records are not complete and many known members of the church are missing. It is not known when the records were written, but most appear to date before 1900. The church history began before 1862, but the earlier information appears incomplete on many older members of the church.

Surviving records from the Southside Pittsburgh First German Baptist Church have been microfilmed by the Western Pennsylvania Genealogical Society and are available at Carnegie Library in Pittsburgh in the WPGS collection in the Pennsylvania Room. Microfilming covered two church register books, approximately 250 Fragebogen (questionnaires with one page for each member, though many members are missing in the surviving records), and the 50th anniversary bulletin in 1912.

In addition, articles on these records have been published in the WPGS Quarterly (all 2007): 1. Vol 33 #3 lists dates and places of birth for immigrant members of the church listed in the Fragebogen; 2. Vol 34 #1 lists information for members of the church who converted to the Baptist faith in Germany and discusses the difficulties encountered by modern German Baptists (not the Anabaptists, though the legacy of the Anabaptists affected the modern Baptists) in Germany in the mid-1800s; and 3. Vol 34 #2 lists information on marriages and children, based on the Fragebogen and partially on the church registers. Not all information in the church registers has been covered by these articles, and the researcher is encouraged to consult the original records at Carnegie Library.

See also History of the churches of the Pittsburgh Baptist Association by William Russell Pankey on the website of the University of Pittsburgh Library for 'Historic Pittsburgh'. In 1918 the congregation changed the name to Temple Baptist and moved to Brownsville Road in Carrick, where these records were recently discovered.

Lysbeth ewaltman at umich dot edu 20 December 2009

Dates and Places of Birth for Immigrant Members

First German Baptist Church, Pittsburgh

based on the Historischer Fragebogen

Clearly identified maiden names are listed in parentheses, and women are listed alphabetically by their married names, as they were listed in the church records. Terms and abbreviations used in the original records include: Kreis (district), Bez./Bezirk (district), Regbz./Regierungsbezirk (administrative area), Amt (office, ministry), Abtei (Abbey), Grossh./Großherzogtum (grand-duchy), O/Preussen (Ost Preussen), a/ (adjacent to), and getauft (baptized).

Members from Oberkaufungen and Niederkaufungen Kurhessen

Members of the First German Baptist Church immigrated from many villages in Germany and East Prussia. However, at least 60 immigrant members of the congregation were born in the villages of Oberkaufungen and Niederkaufungen, Kurhessen, about 10 km east of the city of Kassel. Again, this may not be a complete list.

Women are listed here by their maiden surnames where known.
